g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Adapter (=Wrapper) Convert the interface of a class to anothe...
g.text: Adapter (=Wrapper)Convert the interface of a class to another interface that the client expects or requires.

g.title: Folded Corner.20
g.desc: The Adaptee and Target interface could be ‘deeply’ intertwine...

g.text: The Adaptee and Target interface could be ‘deeply’ intertwined with the rest of our system (see ‘When?’ (1)). Modifying these interfaces would cause the production and test code to break in multiple places and thus generate an extensive amount of work and increased risk in bug introduction. An Adapter overcomes this change and provides us the conversion between interfaces (bi- and/or unidirectional). This compliments the OCP, because we don’t modify existing code, instead we introduce a new class with the responsibility to make the interfaces between sub-parts of our system compatible. On top of that, in case we need a different Adapter (e.g. we want to have a new Adaptee), our client remains untouched due to the applicability of DIP between client and adapter.

g.title: Rectangle.28
g.desc: Adapters introduce a layer of indirection
g.text: Adapters introduce a layer of indirection

g.title: Rectangle.45
g.desc: (2)To simplify an existing interface that we cannot change (e...
g.text: (2)To simplify an existing interface that we cannot change (e.g. libraries)

g.title: Rectangle.47
g.desc: (1)To connect two incompatible, existing interfaces, that we ...
g.text: (1)To connect two incompatible, existing interfaces, that we cannot change (e.g. libraries).

g.title: Rectangle.52
g.desc: (3)Subclasses lack common functionality, but the base class m...
g.text: (3)Subclasses lack common functionality, but the base class may not be extended

g.title: Folded Corner.54
g.desc: It could be that we want to extend our subclasses with new fu...

g.text: It could be that we want to extend our subclasses with new functionality, but we cannot extend the base class. A solution could be to add this additional code to the concrete classes, however this will result in duplicate code. To ‘share’ this functionality we can ‘wrap’ the concrete classes in an adapter and overcome duplicate code.

g.title: Folded Corner.57
g.desc: It might be ‘simpler’ to just modify the Adaptee to fit the r...

g.text: It might be ‘simpler’ to just modify the Adaptee to fit the required Target interface, instead of introducing an extra class that creates an additional form of indirection (negative impact on debugging and navigating through the code), needs testing and adds additional maintenance.

g.title: Folded Corner.64
g.desc: The logic to convert one interface into another is separated ...

g.text: The logic to convert one interface into another is separated from client logic. This compliments the SRP, because we extracted conversion logic from our client, to gain readability, clarify point of change and reduce the risk of introducing bugs in client code incase the adapter needs modification.

g.title: Folded Corner.69
g.desc: we can decide to apply an Adapter In case multiple clients wi...

g.text: we can decide to apply an Adapter In case multiple clients will be dependent on the Adaptee, but the interface it provides is too extensive (see ‘When?’ (2)). This means we use the Adapter to overcome coupling of our clients to methods it does not use. Introducing a ‘narrowed’ interface ensures less re-compilation and changes in our test code, because changes in uninterested methods will not impact our mocks and recompilation in our system. The impact will be reduced to our Adapter.

g.title: Folded Corner.73
g.desc: It could be that we need to introduce new functionality into ...

g.text: It could be that we need to introduce new functionality into our system. A requirement is that the new functionality should be compatible with an already existing interface X. The new functionality can be obtained by an existing library Y. To connect interface X and Y we introduce an adapter.

g.title: Folded Corner.75
g.desc: Our software needs to communicate to an external hardware dev...

g.text: Our software needs to communicate to an external hardware device. This hardware device has interface Y. Our software needs a simplified version of this extensive hardware interface. We introduce an adapter to convert extensive interface Y to a newly, simplified interface X.
